SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Dept of Agriculture & Land Stewardship

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tanks, nurse tanks, application equipment, plumbing, fill hoses and valves, shut-off valves

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:	Edler-Eggers Fertilizer, 2124 Eastman Ave., State Center, IA 50247
Contact:	Dave Eggers 
Phone:		641-483-2770 or 641- 483-2454

1.	Facility Policy.
	
	The owners of Edler-Eggers Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the State Center Fire Department (641-483-2559), Marshall County Emergency Management Agency (641-754-6385) or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.  
	
2.	Facility Information.

The primary activity at the facility is the storage of  Anhydrous Ammonia fertilizer.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application for crop production nutrients.


3..	Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility has been reviewed for general compliance with the provisions of Safety Requirements for the Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI), and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  The ANSI Standard has been adopted by reference by Iowa Administrative Code Part 21-Chapter 43-Rule 43.6(200)-Standard for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  The OSHA standard is referenced in the Registration Form Section 8.3.b.

The whole facility is kept up to date with regards to the Iowa Department of Agriculture Inspections. The facility is inspected onnc a year by Iowa Department of Agriculture. I inspect the facility before the spring use and after the season use before fall. The facility is only in use an average of four weeks per year.

To help prevent against either of these events happening, breakaway couplings for pull away protection are used on the fill hoses to prevent against hose ru

pture should someone pull away with a tank that is being filled. Valves to the main tank are covered and locked. Excess flow valves are used on the main tank. Remote emergency manual shutoffs are in place to minimize loss. Water hydrant is on-site for emergency water.

4.	Five-Year Accident History.		

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  

5.	Emergency Response Program.

	The facility has:

a.	A written action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38; If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the State Center Fire Department (641-483-2559), Marshall County Emergency Management Agency (641-754-6385) or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the people and the environment.  

b.	Provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

6.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  

There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding storage or use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
